abstract.text: A brief review of the experimental situation concerning the electrically-charged charmoniumlike meson candidates, Z − , is presented.

body_text.text: Introduction

The Belle Collaboration reported peaks in the ψ ′ π − [1] and χ c1 π − invariant mass distributions [2] in B → ψ ′ π − K [3] and B → χ c1 π − K [4], respectively. If these peaks are meson resonances, they would have a minimal quark substructure of ccdū and be unmistakeably exotic. However, even though the Belle signals have more than 5σ statistical significance, the experimental situation remains uncertain in that none of these peaks have yet been confirmed by other experiments. An analysis by the BABAR Collaboration of B → ψ ′ π − K neither confirms nor contradicts the Belle claim for the Z(4430) − → ψ ′ π − [5]. In the BABAR analysis, B → J/ψπ − K decays were also studied, and no evidence for Z(4430) − → J/ψπ − was found.
In this paper, we review and compare Belle and BABAR results on searches for charged charmoniumlike states. An abbreviated version of this review is contained in Ref. [6].
The Belle observation

Belle's original Z(4430) − signal [3] is the sharp peak in the ψ ′ π − invariant mass distribution from B → ψ ′ π − K decays shown in Fig. 1. The Belle analysis is based on a data sample that is equivalent to an integrated luminosity of 605 fb −1 . Figure 2 shows the Dalitz plot for B → ψ ′ π − K candidates, where verti-cal bands for K * (892)→Kπ − and K * 2 (1430)→Kπ − are evident and the Z(4430) − shows up as a horizontal band of events between M 2 ψ ′ π − = 19 and 20 GeV 2 /c 4 . (In the ψ ′ π − invariant mass distribution of Fig. 1, the the K * bands are suppressed by cuts on the Kπ − masses [3]).

A binned maximum-likelihood fit to the ψ ′ π − mass distribution using a Breit Wigner (BW) resonance function for the signal and a polynomial background gives a mass of M = 4433 ± 4 ± 2 MeV/c 2 and total width of Γ = 45 +18 +30

−13 −13 MeV, with estimated statistical significance of more than 6σ. Consistent signals are seen in various subsets of the data: i.e. for both the ψ ′ → ℓ + ℓ − (ℓ = e, or µ) and ψ ′ → J/ψπ + π − (J/ψ → ℓ + ℓ − ) subsamples [3].
A reflection from Kπ dynamics?

Identifying resonant structures in the ψ ′ π − channel in three-body B → ψ ′ π − K decays has to be done with care because of the possibility that dynamics in the Kπ − channel can cause mass structures in the ψ ′ π − invariant mass distribution that have no relation to ψ ′ π − dynamics. Energy-momentum conservation imposes a tight correlation between the decay angle (θ π − ) in the Kπ − system [7] and the ψ ′ π − invariant mass, and this results in M 2 ψ ′ π − being very nearly proportional to cos θ π − . Consequently, interference between different partial waves in the Kπ − system can produce peaks in M ψ ′ π − that are purely "reflections" of structures in cos θ π − and have nothing to do with ψ ′ π − dynamics. However, in the kinematically allowed Kπ − mass range for B → ψ ′ π − K decay, only S-, P -and D-waves are significant, and this limited set of partial waves can only produce fake ψ ′ π − mass peaks at a discrete set of mass values.

In the case of the Z(4430) − , the ψ ′ π − peak mass  corresponds to cos θ π − ≃ 0.25, and it is not possible to produce a peak near this cos θ π − value with any combination of interfering L =0, 1, and 2 partial waves without introducing additional, larger structures at other cos θ π − values. This is illustrated in Fig. 3, where the histogram shows the distribution of cos θ π − values for a MC sample of B → Z(4430) − K, Z(4430) − →ψ ′ π − events where the Z(4430) − mass and width closely correspond to Belle's reported values [3]. The curves in the figure show the results of trying to make a peak at the same location with interfering S-, P -and D-partial waves in the Kπ − channel. (Here both longitudinally and transversely polarized ψ ′ 's are considered, and no attempt is made to restrict the strength of each term to that seen for the S-, P -and D-wave Kπ − components in the data.) These curves show that although a peak can be made at cos θ π − ≃ 0.25, it is necessarily accompanied by large enhancements near cos θ π − ≃ ±1. The BABAR search for the Z(4430) − BABAR searched [5] for the Z(4430) − in the decay modes B → ψπ − K, where ψ = J/ψ or ψ ′ and K = K + or K 0 S . The search was performed using the full BABAR data set equivalent to integrated luminosity of 413 fb −1 (455×10 6 BB candidates) collected at a center-of-mass energy of 10.58 GeV. The BABAR search covered two additional decay modes (B → J/ψπ − K) that were not considered in the Belle study. The J/ψ modes contain about six times (see Table II in Ref. [5]) more data than those with the ψ ′ and provide a powerful, high statistics tool for understanding the background. The Dalitz plots for the four decay modes are shown in Fig. 4. The Kπ − mass distribution shows a clear K * (892) signal in all decay modes, and a visible K * 2 (1430) signal in the modes with a J/ψ but less significant in the modes with ψ ′ . Since the Kπ − system dominates the Dalitz plot, the BABAR Collaboration studied the Kπ − mass distribution and the angular dependence. Similar contributions from the different wave intensities are obtained in the modes with K 0 S and K + (see Table III in Ref. [5]) and, therefore, the modes with K 0 S and K + are combined. The Kπ − mass distributions are fitted 12 and 13 in Ref. [5]). The BABAR mass resolution at the Z(4430) − mass is 7 (4) MeV/c 2 for the modes with J/ψ (ψ ′ ) (see Fig. 6 in Ref. [5]). Each event is efficiency corrected, and the conclusions are based on distributions obtained after background subtraction. The average efficiency varies slightly as a function of the Kπ − mass but can differ significantly between the different ψ decay modes (see Fig. 7 in Ref. [5]), however there are significant variations in efficiency with cos θ K for certain regions of Kπ − mass (see Fig. 36 in Ref. [5]).

This comparison is essential to investigate the need for a Z(4430) − signal above the Kπ − reflection. Following the five Kπ − regions (see section 10.D in Ref. In each figure, a comparison (not a fit) between the data and the Kπ − reflection is shown. Note that only one normalization factor for the Kπ − regions is used for each ψ mode. The Kπ − reflections onto the ψπ − mass distributions describe well the data, with a small statistical fluctuation at m Kπ − < 0.795 GeV/c 2 . The ψπ − mass distribution and the overall Kπ − projection are shown in Fig. 7. No significant evidence for Z(4430) − has been obtained. The Kπ − projection onto the ψπ − mass distribution is used as a nonpeaking background. With such a background shape and a BW function for a Z(4430) − signal, a signal is obtained for the overall Kπ − region, but with shifted mass value. A similar small signal is obtained in the K * (892) and K * 2 (1430) combined regions. A ∼ 2σ peak is obtained when the K * (892) and K * 2 (1430) regions are vetoed. No (or a negative) signal for Z(4430) − → J/ψπ − was found. The fit with the Z(4430) − is favored over the fit with no Z(4430) − by 6.4σ. The fitted mass, M = 4443 +15 +19

Variations of the fit that included a J = 1 assignment for the Z(4430) − as well as models that included additional, hypothetical K * →Kπ − resonances with floating masses and widths, and radically different parameterizations of the Kπ − S-wave amplitude do not change the conclusions. The product branching fraction from the Dalitz fit: 8 +9.6 −0.9 −1.6 ) × 10 −5 is not in strong contradiction with the BABAR 95% C.L. upper limit of 3.1 × 10 −5 [5].   Belle's two Z peaks in the χ c1 π − channel In addition to the Z(4430) − , Belle has presented results of an analysis of B → χ c1 π − K decays that require two resonant states in the χ c1 π − channel [4]. The M 2 Kπ − vs. M 2 χ c1 π − Dalitz plot, shown in Fig. 11, shows vertical bands of events corresponding to K * (892)→Kπ − and K * 2 (1430)→Kπ − , plus a broad horizontal band near M 2 χ c1 π − ≃ 17.5 GeV 2 /c 4 , indicating a possible resonance in the χ c1 π − channel. In this case, this horizontal band corresponds to cos θ π − ≃ 0, a location where interference between partial waves in the Kπ − channel can produce a peak and, thus, a detailed Dalitz analysis is essential.

For B → χ c1 π − K, the kinematically allowed mass range for the Kπ − system extends beyond the K * 3 (1780) F -wave resonance and S-, P -, Dand F -wave terms for the Kπ − system are included in the model. The fit with a single resonance in the Z − → χ c1 π − channel is favored over a fit with only K * resonances and no Z − by more than 10σ. Moreover, a fit with two resonances in the χ c1 π − channel is favored over the fit with only one Z − resonance by  The product branching fractions for B → Z − (→ χ c1 π − )K have central values similar to that for the Z(4430) − but with large errors. Figure 12 shows the M χ c1 π − projection of the Dalitz plot with the K * bands excluded and the results of the fit with no Z − → χ c1 π − resonances and with two Z − → χ c1 π − resonances.
Summary

If the peaks reported by Belle in the ψ ′ π − and χ c1 π − channels are in fact meson resonances, they would be "smoking guns" for exotics. It is therefore important that the Belle results are confirmed statistics. However, both experiments have completed data taking and the BABAR analysis used their complete dataset while the Belle analysis used about 75% of their final total data sample. Approximately 3 ab −1 of integrated luminosity would be necessary to bring the ψ ′ π − sample to the statistical level of BABAR's current J/ψπ − sample, and this amount of data will not be available until the operation of one of the Super-B factories, which will not happen for at least a few years. In the meantime, it would be valuable if BABAR performed a search for the Z 1 (4050) − and Z 2 (4250) − in the χ c1 π − channel and Belle reproduced BABAR's study of the J/ψ π − channel using the existing data sets. The D0 and CDF experiments at the Tevatron have data on hand that could be used to carry out searches for inclusive production of the Z(4430) − and we hope that results will be available from them in the near future.
